# Little black dress

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

For other uses, see [Little Black Dress
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Little_Black_Dress_\(disambiguation\) "Little Black
Dress \(disambiguation\)").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Anneke_Gr%C3%B6nloh_1964_Eurovision_dress.jpg/225px-
Anneke_Gr%C3%B6nloh_1964_Eurovision_dress.jpg)](/wiki/File:Anneke_Gr%C3%B6nloh_1964_Eurovision_dress.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Anneke_Gr%C3%B6nloh_1964_Eurovision_dress.jpg "Enlarge")

A little black dress from 1964

A **little black dress** (**LBD**) is a black [evening](/wiki/Evening_gown
"Evening gown") or [cocktail dress](/wiki/Cocktail_dress "Cocktail dress"),
cut simply and often quite short. [Fashion
historians](/wiki/History_of_fashion_design "History of fashion design")
ascribe the origins of the little black dress to the 1920s designs of [Coco
Chanel](/wiki/Coco_Chanel "Coco Chanel") and [Jean Patou](/wiki/Jean_Patou
"Jean Patou")[1] intended to be long-lasting, versatile, affordable,
accessible to the widest market possible and in a neutral colour. Its ubiquity
is such that it is often simply referred to as the "LBD".[2][3][4]

The "little black dress" is considered essential to a complete
[wardrobe](/wiki/Clothing "Clothing") by many women and fashion observers, who
believe it a "rule of fashion" that every woman should own a simple, elegant
black dress that can be dressed up or down depending on the occasion: for
example, worn with a jacket and pumps for daytime business wear or with more
ornate jewelry and accessories for evening or a formal event such as a
[wedding](/wiki/Wedding "Wedding") or a [ball](/wiki/Ball_\(dance_party\)
"Ball \(dance party\)"). Because it is meant to be a staple of the wardrobe
for a number of years, the style of the little black dress ideally should be
as simple as possible: a short black dress that is too clearly part of a trend
would not qualify because it would soon appear dated.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Little_black_dress&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This section **does not[cite](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources") any [sources](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this section](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Little_black_dress&action=edit) by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1 "Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may be challenged and [removed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence "Wikipedia:Verifiability"). _(March 2017)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
Black has always been [a color rich in
symbolism](/wiki/Black#Associations_and_symbolism "Black"). In the early 18th
century, black represented romance and artistry. As [Ann
Demeulemeester](/wiki/Ann_Demeulemeester "Ann Demeulemeester") said of it,
"Black is poetic. How do you imagine a poet? In a bright yellow jacket?
Probably not." In the early 19th century, black was adopted by the
[Romantics](/wiki/Romantics "Romantics") such as [Byron](/wiki/Byron "Byron"),
[Shelley](/wiki/Shelley "Shelley"), and [Keats](/wiki/Keats "Keats"), due to
its melancholic aura. As the [Victorian Era](/wiki/Victorian_Era "Victorian
Era") began, black transitions from a color of art to one of grief and
mourning - widows were expected to wear black for at least four years - and
also for service livery, as the uniform for [maids](/wiki/Maid "Maid").

  
In 1926 [Gabrielle "Coco" Chanel](/wiki/Gabrielle_Chanel "Gabrielle Chanel")
published a picture of a short, simple black dress in American
_[Vogue](/wiki/Vogue_\(magazine\) "Vogue \(magazine\)")_. It was calf-length,
straight and decorated only by a few diagonal lines. _Vogue_ called it
"Chanel's Ford". Like the [Model T](/wiki/Model_T "Model T"), the little black
dress was simple and accessible for women of all social classes. _Vogue_ also
said that the LBD would become "a sort of uniform for all women of taste".[5]
This, as well as other designs by the house of Chanel helped disassociate
black with mourning, and reinvent it as the uniform of the high-class,
wealthy, and chic. As Coco herself proclaimed, "I imposed black; it's still
going strong today, for black wipes out everything else around."[6] Chanel is
credited with the creation and popularization of the Little Black Dress, and
rightfully so.

The little black dress continued to be popular through the [Great
Depression](/wiki/Great_Depression "Great Depression"), predominantly through
its economy and elegance, albeit with the line lengthened somewhat.
[Hollywood](/wiki/Hollywood "Hollywood")'s influence on fashion helped the
little black dress's popularity, but for more practical reasons: as
[Technicolor](/wiki/Technicolor "Technicolor") films became more common,
filmmakers relied on little black dresses because other colors looked
distorted on screen and botched the coloring process. During [World War
II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), the style continued in part due to
widespread rationing of textiles, and in part as a common uniform
(accessorized for businesswear) for civilian women entering the workforce.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/12-promotional-
models-Fenasucro-2010.JPG/200px-12-promotional-models-
Fenasucro-2010.JPG)](/wiki/File:12-promotional-models-Fenasucro-2010.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:12-promotional-models-Fenasucro-2010.JPG "Enlarge")

Models wearing little black dresses in [Brazil](/wiki/Brazil "Brazil"), 2010

The rise of [Dior's "New Look"](/wiki/The_New_Look_\(style\) "The New Look
\(style\)") in the post-war era and the sexual conservatism of the 1950s
returned the little black dress to its roots as a uniform and a symbol of the
dangerous woman. Hollywood [femme fatales](/wiki/Femme_fatale "Femme fatale")
and [fallen women](/wiki/Fallen_women "Fallen women") characters were
portrayed often in black halter-style dresses in contrast to the more
conservative dresses of housewives or more wholesome Hollywood stars.
Synthetic fibres made popular in the 1940s and 1950s broadened the
availability and affordability of many designs.

The generation gap of the 1960s created a dichotomy in the design of the
little black dress. The younger "[mod](/wiki/Mod "Mod")" generation preferred,
in general, a miniskirt on their versions of the dress and designers catering
to the [youth culture](/wiki/Youth_culture "Youth culture") continued to push
the envelope - shortening the skirt even more, creating cutouts or slits in
the skirt or bodice of the dress, using sheer fabrics such as
[netting](/wiki/Netting "Netting") or [tulle](/wiki/Tulle "Tulle"). Many women
aspired to simple black sheath dresses similar to the [black Givenchy
dress](/wiki/Black_Givenchy_dress_of_Audrey_Hepburn "Black Givenchy dress of
Audrey Hepburn") worn by [Audrey Hepburn](/wiki/Audrey_Hepburn "Audrey
Hepburn") in the film _[Breakfast at
Tiffany's](/wiki/Breakfast_at_Tiffany%27s_\(film\) "Breakfast at Tiffany's
\(film\)")_.

The popularity of casual fabrics, especially knits, for dress and business
wear during the 1980s brought the little black dress back into vogue. Coupled
with the fitness craze, the new designs incorporated details already popular
at the time such as broad shoulders or [peplums](/wiki/Overskirt "Overskirt"):
later in the decade and into the 1990s, simpler designs in a variety of
lengths and fullness were popular. The
[grunge](/wiki/Grunge#Presentation_and_fashion "Grunge") culture of the 1990s
saw the combination of the little black dress with both sandals and [combat
boots](/wiki/Combat_boots "Combat boots"), though the dress itself remained
simple in cut and fabric.

The new glamour of the late 1990s led to new variations of the dress but, like
the 1950s and the 1970s, colour re-emerged as a factor in fashion and
formalwear and repeatedly shows an aversion to black. The resurgence of body
conscious clothing, muted colour schemes, and the reemergence of predominant
black, along with the retrospective trends of the 1980s in the late 2000s
paved way to the return of interest to the dress.

## Famous little black
dresses[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Little_black_dress&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Famous little black dresses")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Lena_Oslo3_cropped.jpg/150px-
Lena_Oslo3_cropped.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lena_Oslo3_cropped.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Lena_Oslo3_cropped.jpg "Enlarge")

[Eurovision Song Contest](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest "Eurovision Song
Contest") winner, [Lena](/wiki/Lena_Meyer-Landrut "Lena Meyer-Landrut"),
sporting a little black dress and black [stockings](/wiki/Stocking "Stocking")
while singing her winning song "[Satellite](/wiki/Satellite_\(Lena_Meyer-
Landrut_song\) "Satellite \(Lena Meyer-Landrut song\)")".

The [black Givenchy dress of Audrey
Hepburn](/wiki/Black_Givenchy_dress_of_Audrey_Hepburn "Black Givenchy dress of
Audrey Hepburn") as Holly Golightly in _[Breakfast at
Tiffany’s](/wiki/Breakfast_at_Tiffany%27s_\(film\) "Breakfast at Tiffany's
\(film\)")_ , designed by [Hubert de Givenchy](/wiki/Hubert_de_Givenchy
"Hubert de Givenchy"), epitomized the standard for wearing little black
dresses accessorized with pearls (together called "basic black"), as was
frequently seen throughout the early 1960s. The dress set a record in 2006
when it was auctioned for £410,000, six times its original estimate.[7] [Betty
Boop](/wiki/Betty_Boop "Betty Boop"), a cartoon character based in part on the
1920s' "It Girl" [Clara Bow](/wiki/Clara_Bow "Clara Bow"), was drawn wearing a
little black dress in her early films, though with
[Technicolor](/wiki/Technicolor "Technicolor") later, Betty's dress became
red.[5]

[Wallis Simpson](/wiki/Wallis_Simpson "Wallis Simpson"), Duchess of Windsor,
was known to own several little black dresses and said much in praise of the
garments. One quote of the Duchess: "When a little black dress is right, there
is nothing else to wear in its place."[5] [Edith Piaf](/wiki/Edith_Piaf "Edith
Piaf"), the French folk icon, performed in a black sheath dress throughout her
career: for this habit she was nicknamed "little black sparrow". It was
thought that the dress helped audiences focus more on Piaf's singing and less
on her appearance.[5]

In an incident at [London](/wiki/London "London")'s [Covent
Garden](/wiki/Covent_Garden "Covent Garden") theatre in 2004, a director fired
the then-[obese](/wiki/Obseity "Obseity") [soprano](/wiki/Soprano "Soprano")
[Deborah Voigt](/wiki/Deborah_Voigt "Deborah Voigt") from an
[opera](/wiki/Opera "Opera") because she could not fit into a "little black
cocktail dress", replacing her with the slimmer [Anne
Schwanewilms](/wiki/Anne_Schwanewilms "Anne Schwanewilms").[8][9][10][11]

## In popular
culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Little_black_dress&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: In popular culture")]

---|---  
  
A number of songs are titled "Little Black Dress", including "Little Black
Dress" from the 1981 musical _[Shock Treatment](/wiki/Shock_Treatment "Shock
Treatment")_ , which is sung whilst one of the antagonists sews up a little
black dress and presents it to the heroine, who wears it in the second half of
the film.

[The Hollies](/wiki/The_Hollies "The Hollies") 1972 Single "Long Cool Woman in
a Black Dress" was written for the album _[Distant
Light](/wiki/Distant_Light_\(The_Hollies_album\) "Distant Light \(The Hollies
album\)")_ about a woman who mesmerized the lead singer in a black dress. It
sold 2 million copies worldwide and reached #2 on the [Billboards Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100")

[Gavin Friday](/wiki/Gavin_Friday "Gavin Friday") performed a song titled
"Little Black Dress" for his 1996 album _[Shag Tobacco](/wiki/Shag_Tobacco
"Shag Tobacco")_. The song was written by [Maurice
Seezer](/wiki/Maurice_Seezer "Maurice Seezer").

The 2006 song "Little Black Dress" is the opening song of [Donnie
Iris](/wiki/Donnie_Iris "Donnie Iris")'s album, _[Ellwood
City](/wiki/Ellwood_City_\(album\) "Ellwood City \(album\)")_. It was written
by [Mark Avsec](/wiki/Mark_Avsec "Mark Avsec").

"[Gettin' You Home (The Black Dress
Song)](/wiki/Gettin%27_You_Home_\(The_Black_Dress_Song\) "Gettin' You Home
\(The Black Dress Song\)")" is a 2009 country music song by [Chris
Young](/wiki/Chris_Young_\(singer\) "Chris Young \(singer\)"). It became his
first #1 hit on the [Hot Country Songs](/wiki/Hot_Country_Songs "Hot Country
Songs") chart dated for 24 October 2009.

"Tiffany Blews" is the 10th track on [Fall Out Boy](/wiki/Fall_Out_Boy "Fall
Out Boy")'s 4th studio album, [Folie à Deux](/wiki/Folie_%C3%A0_Deux_\(album\)
"Folie à Deux \(album\)"). The chorus mentions a little black dress, a symbol
for classiness.

"Little Black Dress" is a song by [One Direction](/wiki/One_Direction "One
Direction") included in their third album entitled _[Midnight
Memories](/wiki/Midnight_Memories "Midnight Memories")_.

"Little Black Dress" is also a song by [Sara Bareilles](/wiki/Sara_Bareilles
"Sara Bareilles"), the 6th track on 2013's _[The Blessed
Unrest](/wiki/The_Blessed_Unrest "The Blessed Unrest")_ album. In the song,
dancing in the dress promotes getting over a relationship.

"Little Black Dress" is a song by San Diego–based roots reggae band One Drop,
from the 2008 release _Mission Blvd_.[12]
